Author: jl777c#5810
Content: delta neutral portfolio is the balancing concept

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a delta neutral portfolio doesnt care if the price goes up or down as all positions are hedged

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: of course we cant practically achieve 100% delta neutrality... however we can push things to come close to it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so, lets imagine we add the ability for all existing positions to have their opposite bet listed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: covering the opposite position would be offered at some discount, or we charge a bigger premium to create an initial position

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the house edge can simply be the 24hr min/max, so the initial position and covered position will have different costbasis and this difference is the house profit margin

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe this allows us to offer covering an existing position without any fee

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and we charge something like a 1% fee to create a new position

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this then creates an "orderbook" of unbalanced bets that people can choose to make, it should be displayed in the reversed form so people can just see what bet they can make without a fee, they still need the deposit of course

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a complication is that as funds are added, it seems such adding of funds creates the opposite orderbook entry for the amount of new funds

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with this, we can see the total exposure is the sum of the unfilled "orderbook"

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and that due to not needing a fee, people will naturally tend to balance the portfolio over creating a new position

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with such a total exposure that is constantly reduced with the opposite orderbook, we can then cap the amount of new positions allowed, ie. once the max net exposure is reached, no new positions are allowed, only bets that reduce the exposure via opposite orderbook
